segments.text: Fall morning, October 29, Friday morning, and I'm chatting with Mrs. Jack Kenny Williams, looking out beyond her orchid area.
Now, Mrs. Williams, say a sentence or two, and let's test your mic.
Just anything.
Good morning.
I'm glad you're here.
It's a treat.
Now, let's... See that beautiful...
Mrs. Williams, how did you and Dr. Williams first meet?
You were back in college?
Yeah, we were in college.
He was a junior and I was a freshman.
And my mother had given my brother a package of skirts that had been left behind to be re-hemmed.
I don't know whether they were supposed to be shorter or longer.
And after a fraternity meeting, my brother asked Jack to bring those skirts to me because we ate in the same dining hall.
And he told someone to tell him that my skirts were behind the mirror in that foyer.
And when I walked in, he asked somebody who that was.
We didn't eat at the same table.
And he decided he would tell me himself.
Now, this was at Emory & Henry College?
At Emory & Henry College in Virginia.
It's a Methodist school.
About how many students?
How big was it?
It wasn't large.
I don't remember at that time, and this is 38.
Three or four hundred students, probably.
And how soon was it before he asked you for a date?
I don't remember.

He sort of hung around all the meals, sent me a flower from his table, and he would pull a marigold out of the vase or whatever it was and bring it over, send it over by the waiter, but I don't remember.
It was a long time before he asked me if he could kiss me.
So y'all... That was months.
He asked me if I'd been vaccinated.
That was a cute little thing that some girl had said at a pep meeting.
They say kisses have germs, but you can kiss me because I've been vaccinated.
Did you ever hear that?
Did he have a sense of humor then as a young man?
I don't know.
I don't remember it registering with me at the time.
Because I think I always remember his great sense of humor when I knew him.
His sense of humor was almost sarcasm.
Have you noticed?
No.
No, I wouldn't describe it as sarcasm, but... You know, sarcastic, you know, in a way, things he'd say was not...
He was always kind, but funny.
The girls and I giggled at him all the time.
How long before you all became serious in your romance?
Weeks, months, years?
I don't know.
I don't know how serious he was.
He dated so many girls along the line, and we dated a lot, even the first year.
I guess we were both serious before summer came.
Did, at Emory & Henry, did people get, in the fraternity and sorority, was there a special kind of pinning or anything like that?
Did you all do that?
These were social sorority clubs, they say.
They were not national at that time.
You know, this is 38.
This is Depression years.
But we had rush parties and that type of thing, and he was already in the fraternity.
He was two years ahead of me.
Jack went to college at 16.
I went to college at 18 because I'd been living in West Virginia where they had one more extra year, and Virginia had one less.
And I think he skipped, his mother taught him to read before he ever started the school, and I think he skipped a year, I'm not sure.
Was he a history major when you began?
No, no, he was pre-law.
He majored in political science.
And when he graduated, his main professor had him a scholarship or fellowship, scholarship it would be,
for Vanderbilt.
In law?
All right, but he doesn't go to law school, does he?
No, the war came along, and money was scarier than his family, and he said he had to get a job and earn his own money way from then on because his father had two more children to educate.
And then the war came along, and you know what happened.
But he did teach two years before, after he joined the Marine Corps in December the 8th.
He joined the Marine Corps, I think that's in there.
And it... Now that's December 8th, 1941, the day after Pearl Harbor.
He was on the campus with me when it happened.
And...
He joined the Marine Corps the next day.
But they had to wait until he could be placed in an officer's school.
So many joined, they had to just take them a few at a time or whatever it was.
Do you remember the two of you talking about Pearl Harbor and what it might mean to your lives?
No.
Because so many of us are, you know, where were you when you heard the news of Pearl Harbor?
We were in the parlor of my dormitory, and I had three or four sorority sisters or friends in the room, and we had a radio playing, and Jack was taking turns dancing with them.
And I was sitting on the sofa listening to it all.
So he liked to dance.
His father had dancing lessons.
I was a preacher's daughter, and it was sinful for preacher's children to dance at that time, you know, and I had to just start dancing without any lessons.
But he was used to going to the girls' schools and having a stag line.
But I brought that to an end.
He only went to one more after he met me.
And he broke a date to do it.
Now, did you tell him not to go?
No, I knew he was going.
I don't like this being recorded.
Anyway, he said, would I go to the first football game with him?
And when I told him when it was, either that day or later, there was a dead silence.
And I knew that
The day of the football game came, he did not mention picking me up for the football game, and I knew where he was.
He was down enjoying that stag line.
He had had a date already to go down there, and he didn't break it with whoever it was.
He broke it with me.
It was never mentioned.
By him or me.
Things just picked up and went right on.
And he didn't mention the fact that I told my friends that I knew Jackson would break a date with me tonight.
Now, when did y'all get serious and when were you thinking about getting married?
And was he already in the service?
No, no.
My daddy brought that to a head.
I was invited to go visit a friend in Galax, Jackson Town.
She and I had met in church young people's programs.
And I was invited to go.
He may have put that together, but anyway, I wanted to go and I asked about getting permission to go visit Jack, although I was going to stay with this other friend.
And my father said, are you considering marrying Jack?
And I had never thought about it.
And I said, well, I guess so.
And he said, then I think you should go.
See what kind of father I had?
That also seems like your father was giving his approval.
Oh, when Jack came to visit, the two of them,
Both of them loved history, and they would spend hours talking and discussing history.
They were the best of friends.
Oh, that's marvelous.
Now, when did you all get married?
June the 10th, 1943.
See, that's five years from the time we met.
But also just before he leaves for active duty?
In the Pacific.
He left January the 10th.
We got married in June, and he left, I think it was January the 10th.
And where did you spend those months while he was gone?
In Radford, Virginia, with my parents, working for a Hercules powder plant.
In an office, of course, checking inventory that was in the receiving department.
And how often did he write letters?
Well, we both wrote practically every day, but when he knew that he was going into combat, he said, no, you won't hear from me for a while.
He told me later he didn't want me to hear from a dead man, get a letter from a dead man.
And he went to the Pacific and made what landings?
Didn't he?
What islands did they land on?
I can't remember the name of the first one.
I wanted to say Roy Namor, but that wasn't.
But the final one where he was evacuated was Saipan.
Saipan.
And he was wounded there, wasn't he?
And where did he recuperate?
On Maui.
Maui, back in Hawaii.
And Roosevelt came into his ward in a wheelchair.
They always say that Roosevelt did not anybody see him in a wheelchair.
He came in in a wheelchair and visited them.
Don't you think that's interesting?
Oh, yeah.
Did Dr. Williams ever comment about Roosevelt?
What did he say about him?
Well, he just said he, you know, wrote that he was there.
But Jack was, at that time, was, I guess, and, you know, I don't know.
He didn't go on a lot about his wounds, and it was just shrapnel.
His body had a whole lot of shrapnel.
I've told you this before about the throbbing scar.
Go ahead.
Go ahead.
He had a scar the size of a dime right over his, I call it jugular vein.
Jugular vein.
Jugular vein.
that throbbed all the time.
So on the left side of his lower neck?
I don't know.
I don't remember the side.
But anyway, it was always so interesting to me to think that this scar was there over the vein and it throbbed.
How did the scar get there?
What happened to the shrapnel that cut that scar?
Why didn't it cut the vein?
It was chilling to look at, to see this scar throb.
Why?

There was shrapnel under the collarbone, stuff that they never got out, of course, but why did it not, he would have bled to death, of course, immediately, carotid artery, is what I was trying to say.
Now, when did you first see him after the war?
Where?
September.
September 45.
Where was it?
Roanoke, Virginia.
I was teaching school and I resigned because I couldn't ask him to come and sit in there while I continued.
And so in March we left for Atlanta for Emory University.
March of 46.
Yeah.
Now why Emory instead of some other school?

He had a friend in Charlie Harris from Georgia who was a graduate of Emory and I think he influenced him to go to Emory and I think it just had to have been Charlie Harris and they were the very best of friends.
We went to his wedding, you know, after we moved to Atlanta and Charlie got married and we went to Valdosta to his wedding.
And he later became a member of the State Board of Education.
And had Dr. Williams decided that he was going to be
A history major?
No, he was going into secondary education.
His teaching had taught him that there was a discipline problem.
And he came back and I said, let's go to Harvard if you're going to be law.
Let's just go to the best school.
And he said, no, I'm going to go into secondary education.
Men are needed in education.
And so anything he said was just fine with me.
You can imagine.
After that time, we were good friends.
How long before he decided that higher education was his goal?
A professor at Emory changed that.
Who was it?
I don't remember.
Was it Bellwine?
It wasn't Bellwine?
No, no, no.
Anyway, Jack was taking history courses.
And he said, this is awful to put in print.
You're wasting your time getting a degree in education.
No, that's not bad to have.
And if you will come over and major in history, we will give you a scholarship.
So this was a historian marketing history.
How did he, was he enthusiastic about the history idea?
He didn't hesitate to make the change.
Neither of us ever went on about anything.
He might tell me that the little girl next door came over and played at the house that day and he had a picture of her in a wastebasket or something like that.
And he criticized one of the members in one of the trailers there on the campus for showing some broken crystal that he had brought back from the war that he had absconded with and was so proud of.
And he was a ministerial student.
Jack was shocked.
You know, we live so close to these people that I got just a good...
view of what people are really like when you have people that we only had a board sidewalk between us.
Did you ever see that place on Emory campus?
No, you weren't born.
Between us and the next trailer.
And these are all veterans, I'll bet.
Yeah.
And while he was at graduate school, what were you doing?
I worked for a dentist in downtown the WWR building.
And I commuted by bus and walked through the campus.
And he came home and cooked the evening meal because he was on the campus to start with.
And he got off at 4 and I got off at 5.
So he decided to cook and that's with life.
How good a cook was he?
He was terrible until I told him to use cookbooks.
I didn't say anything until he admitted that something just hadn't worked out.
And I said, well, start using the meat of givens, encyclopedias of cooking.
I've told you all this before.
Let's see.
Let me take a break.
See, I don't really like to make it personal where I'm concerned.
I don't mind talking about Jack, but I don't want my life in there.
When I fell in love or anything like that, I don't want that in this.
I don't think it's appropriate.
You're back in the vet village.
The...
I'm assuming that when the war is over, almost all of those veterans were determined, determined, determined to get their degree and get on with their life.
When you all went to Emory and Dr. Williams decided to major in history, what did you all think you were going to be doing
Well, he was going to teach from the very first.
That was it.
He wasn't going to be a lawyer.
Okay.
And when he got his master's degree, he said, I'm going to get my job while there's still one.
There's so many people going to be looking for work.
And so we decided he would apply for a place.
And I insisted that it not be as big as Atlanta or small as Emory & Henry.
And so I was using the...

dictionary for a population and I thought Spartanburg South Carolina sounded just great and the Wofford College was there and the girls school was there and he applied and he applied several other places but a professor asked him to apply for Clemson so he said there's a man there I want you to work for and that was Miriam Kynard
K-I-N-A-R-D. Did you all come up for an interview?
Did you come to visit before he was gone?
Jack did.
I was working.
Jack did.
And he went to Wofford, and both of them offered him the same amount of money, Clemson and Wofford.
Really?
$2,700 for nine months' work.
But Clemson had prefabricated houses that were headed for England.
for our military over there and when the war ended they were left on the wharf in South Carolina and Clemson got them.
And that was the deciding point for our coming to Clemson.
So you arrived in Clemson when?
August of 1948.
Describe Clemson College then.
We didn't have an automobile.
Clemson was just a small college town, I guess you'd say.
We had one of most everything, and it was still military.
The first year, there wasn't an office for Jack.
He was assigned to a
table in the library for his office.
So he would come home and he would tell the students, if you want to counsel with me, I will meet you at this bench at our designated time.
And then he would come home.
And the next year he had an office and he shared it with a young man that became his dear friend, Hugh McCauley.
sharing was by accident?
I mean, the fact that it happened to be Macaulay?
It just happened as far as I'm concerned.
What has been the relationship of the Macaulays and the Williams now for 50 years?
Well, we're family.
We are a family.
I feel by their children like they feel like by mine, and we have, we just did a huge
He called me last night to say he was sorry he couldn't be here today, and we joked.
He and I carry on a lot about money.
For years, he invested his own money, and for his mother, and for his children, for his sister who was a widow.
And until he lost his eyesight, he did all this himself, his own investing.
And he was successful with it.
Let's back up.
Bell Wiley.
What was the effect on Dr. Williams' career of having worked for Bell Wiley?
What did he think of Bell Wiley?
Well, they became good friends because he gave his students a chapter to criticize, and Jack was the only one that did.
And so then he gave him the rest of the book.
And they just became friends.
Jack didn't require... See, I don't like to say this.
They said he didn't require any help from him.
He was self-perpetuated.
He just did everything on his own and didn't ask his professors to help.
In fact, he helped Bill Wiley, but Jack just...

did things and they said he was the most outstanding student they ever had because he just didn't he just came in and did his own work and didn't have didn't have to be at Clemson he rose up through the ranks and I know was very proud of his role in the faculty senate and dean of faculties and so forth at A&M I always wondered when my title became dean of faculties
why it was plural and not singular, dean of the faculty.
Then I happened to find an old Clemson catalog, and I found that his title here was dean of faculties, so I thought perhaps that's why he suggested the same title there.
At Clemson, what do you think
gave him the greatest pride of his years here?
What did he accomplish here that you think he was most proud about?
I don't know.
What did he enjoy most at Clemson?
As I said, he didn't come home and say, I enjoyed this today or I didn't.
I think he loved teaching.
And the students, it was obvious that the students respected him.
But he enjoyed his work for the graduate school.
He didn't complain.
He changed a lot of things.
He had a way of making a decision and seeing that it happened.
And when he came home, it was a happy family bit.
We didn't sit around and discuss the university very often.
I had ways of finding out what happened, but it wasn't that he came home and discussed what had gone on that day.
What did he do when you all were here at Clemson?
What did he do to relax?
What was his diversion, his enjoyment activities?
Well, we played a lot of bridge.
We danced.
He loved music.
He read books.
He built those steps out there.
Anything he saw that needed to be done, always he did it, and he had a way of relaxing.
The Marine Corps taught him to relax.
When did you all build this house?
It took us a long time to get a down payment.
We had two children before that, two degrees before that.
Do you remember what the lot cost?
Yeah.
I have two lots.
$1,500 a piece.
I bought the first two lots.
I was on the list.
So when they opened this, got a straight through, I was called.
I was waiting on them.
And I was going to take the one next door.
And it had a ravine in it.
I didn't like the ravine, so I took the next two.
And since then, I've heard one young man who, I had a tree fall on me not long ago.
And he used to live, he was the coach's son, and we lived across the street from him.
And he had sold a lot.
He still has his parents' home.
But he sold one lot for $35,000, not far from here, and there's one on Woodland Way that sold for $50,000.
But I'm in the middle of two.
I can't sell one, and I don't want to.
And I presume that this lot was covered with trees and you had to...
Saw a few trees down to build a house.
They cleared it for us.
It was wooded.
I had a lot of wildflowers at that time.
Catherine, my oldest daughter, and I used to walk down from our apartment and pick wildflowers and take cookies and have a picnic, we called it.
While he was here, while you all were here,
Did Dr. Williams begin his work then with the historically black schools across the South?
I know that he was very highly respected for his work with some of the black schools.
Did that begin here while y'all were here?
Not that I know of.
He worked with Southern Association, you know that, but I don't remember black schools being mentioned.
We integrated without any problem here because it was well planned, and Harvey Gant was the right person to bring in, obviously.
I heard Dr. Williams told me one day about some of that,
Describe Harvey Gant in personality as you remember him as a student.
Well, I didn't know him as a student, of course.
There's a lot in there since I was teaching so much of the time and raising two children and taking care of things that Jack needed me to do.
Harvey Gant had a sense of humor, obviously.

uh... he uh... went into architecture and he would tease the students and say if you make me do this i'll sit by you in the cafeteria now i think that told you a lot about Harvey Gant and why he has been a success he hasn't gone around with a chip on his shoulder since then you know he was the right person
to integrate Clemson College, and they had the right attitude when he came.
And there were no incidents, were there, about him?
Never heard of one.
Never heard of one.
Now, were there women already at Clemson when you all arrived?
Was the student body coeducational?
I don't know.
I don't remember one way or the other where they had some, I don't think so.
I don't think so.
But it could have been that they already had some women here.
That wasn't, you know, my thinking at that time, see, when we moved in,
with no automobile and I didn't work the first year and the second year I went back to work.
I guess I thought more about Bridge than I did what was going on on the campus.
At one time I played Bridge with five different groups and then I quit playing Bridge when
I realized I couldn't go to bridge parties in the afternoon and raise my daughter, so I quit.
When I came back here, old friends called and wanted me to play bridge in their clubs.
I said, you know, I quit when I was raising my children because I couldn't do that, and I've never gone back.
Jack and I had a computer.
We played bridge with a computer, and I still have it.
Do you remember who contacted Dr. Williams about the
commissioner of higher education job in Texas.
Who?
Yeah, I do.
President of University of Houston.
Wait a minute.
I can't remember that name either.
We'll think of it in a minute.
Yeah.
They had worked together in the Southern Association.
Is that where?
He called Jack and said, Jack, I think you ought to come.
I guess Jack had been contacted or had it mentioned to him before.
They finally got the salary up to where you could make it worth your while.
He became commissioner.
I mean, he took the president of the
Medical Center right after Jack.
You mean Mickey LeMaitre?
That wasn't Mickey LeMaitre.
He was with MD Anderson.
Anyway, he quit because he thought it was boring, and it would have been for him.
When you all moved to Austin, what was your impression of Austin as a place to live?
Did you like it?
Was it pleasant?
Well, of course, I didn't think it was a good place to raise children.
because the children were growing up too fast.
They had too much.
I had nice contacts with people.
But once again, Jack was gone most of the time, and I was raising two children.
And I didn't get, in the two years, I wasn't that much involved in, you know, much that was going on because I've always felt not...
